channel.title: maGaming RSS Feed - eurogamer_net

item.title: Black Myth Wukong gets an update that's so big on PS5, you might need to delete the game and redownload it
item.content:encoded:
Black Myth Wukong is getting an update today, 13th October, across all platforms. It's a relatively minor update that fixes bugs and introduces some performance optimisations, but it requires so much space on PlayStation 5 that some players might struggle to install it.

You'll need approximately 93.5GB of free storage space for the update on PS5. As the Black Myth X account explains: "Due to differences in file storage methods, the patch on PS5 will require a relatively large amount of space (approximately 93.5 GB)."

Given that the original game already occupies ~130GB of storage, adding another ~90GB gives a total of 210GB, which is a sizable chunk of an 825GB standard PS5 storage drive (especially when you consider there's about 667GB of working storage after system files are installed). If you struggle to find the space, it might be simpler to delete the entire game and redownload it.

"If the update cannot be completed due to insufficient storage or other reasons, you may continue playing the current version or try deleting the game and redownloading it," said the Black Myth X account.

Why would that work? Because you're not getting 90GB's worth of new content, you're likely redownloading a reordered file structure of the game - redownloading the game, effectively. Better to do it in one 93.5GB lump than doubling up, if that makes sense.

Incidentally, PC players, note your mods - this patch might cause some compatibility issues with them. If it does, uninstall the mods and wait for them to be separately updated.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Black Myth Wukong was a huge success for maker Game Science when it launched last year, selling more than 10m copies despite lukewarm reviews. But more than that, it was a success for Chinese-made games. It seems to be to them what The Witcher was for Polish games: a pace-maker, a trend-setter, an attention- grabber, as Ed found out when he investigated the rise of Chinese-made blockbuster games recently.

Naturally, the game's success has also fuelled development of more Black Myth game experiences at Game Science, though we're not getting a direct sequel but a thematic continuation based around another mythical Chinese figure, Zhong Kui. There's no release date for it yet.



https://www.eurogamer.net/black-myth-wukong-gets-an-update-thats-so-big-on-ps5-you-might-need-to-delete-the-game-and-redownload-it

item.title: First screenshots of Rare's ill-fated Everwild emerge thanks to artist's portfolio website
item.content:encoded:
Screenshots of Rare's now-cancelled Everwild have emerged via the portfolio website of an artist who worked on the game.

The game was first announced back in 2019 as Rare's next big release. It was shown with an animated trailer of colourful environments and beautifully strange fantasy creatures, its visuals making an immediate impact. It was then shown again the following year with a new trailer, showing player Eternals soothing those strange creatures.

Still, it wasn't clear exactly how it would play, but before we had a chance to find out, the game was cancelled earlier this year following widespread layoffs at Microsoft.

Now, screenshots of the game's UI have been spotted by mp1st, reportedly taken from a version of the game close to its cancellation.

The screenshots show the inventory menu, with players able to cycle between Favourites, Figments, Tools, Mosaics, Seeds, and Plants. Figments, in particular, look like strange little plant creatures.

To the right of the menu is an in-game view of the player character standing by a stone circle. While the menus suggest some sort of farming or base-building customisation gameplay, it's unknown if this is the main game or just a side activity.

Other screenshots show a list of graphical settings, while a couple of others give blurry, foggy views of the stylised visuals.

It's not much to go on, admittedly, but it's the only look at the game we've seen beyond the initial trailers.

Back in February of this year, CEO of Microsoft Gaming Phil Spencer commented on the "progress" Rare was making.

"It has been [a while]," he said. "And we've been able to give those teams time in what they're doing which is good and still have a portfolio like we have.

"It's like a dream that Matt [Booty] and I have had for a long time, so it's finally good to be there. We can give those teams time."

Sadly, that time came to an end for Everwild. It's now unclear what the studio will be working on, beyond its live-service pirate game Sea of Thieves.

These screenshots follow a similar leak of the also-cancelled Perfect Dark, Rare's franchise that was set to be rebooted by The Initiative.



https://www.eurogamer.net/first-screenshots-of-rares-ill-fated-everwild-emerge-thanks-to-artists-portfolio-website
